snippet: The decision comes after a global outcry against programs like Prism, which have given spy agencies almost unfettered access to Internet communications.
abstract: British court overseeing intelligence agencies rules that electronic mass surveillance of people's online communications and cellphones is legal, like Prism program revealed by Edward Snowden; Amnesty International and other privacy rights, which brought on complaint, say they will appeal at European Court of Human rights, as Internet privacy rights are generally given greater protection on Continent.
lead_paragraph: The decision comes after a global outcry against programs like Prism, which have given spy agencies almost unfettered access to Internet communications.

headline.main: British Court Rules in Favor of Electronic Surveillance
headline.print_headline: British Court Rules in Favor of Electronic Surveillance
